overview_metadata.overview_subtitle: Solving Systems of Equations and Inequalities
overview_metadata.overview_description: In this lesson, students write a system composed of four linear inequalities to model a situation and graph the system. They use the graph to determine the solution set. Students write a system of linear equations for each of three different situations. They use any method to solve the system before reasoning about the solution in terms of the problem context.

overview_item_data_items: I can use various methods of solving systems of linear equations to determine the better buy or the better job offer.
I can solve systems of linear inequalities with more than two inequalities.
I can interpret solutions to real-world problems.
I can graph the solution to a system of linear inequalities in two variables as the intersection of the corresponding half-planes.
You can model situations about choosing between two options using a system of linear equations or inequalities.
The solution to a real-world problem may depend on where the input values lie relative to the point of intersection.
Depending on the situation, it may be more appropriate to represent the solution using the system using inequalities rather than a single coordinate pair.

overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_descriptio: Students use mathematical reasoning to choose the best option in a real-world situation.

overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_title: Solving Systems of Linear Equations and Inequalities
overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_descriptio: Students write systems of linear equations and systems of linear inequalities to represent a situation.
Students write a system to represent a real-world situation and determine the best option.

overview_item_data_items: If facilitating this lesson without student devices, no additional materials are needed.
To avoid printing additional materials not included in MATHbook (like Activate activities and Session Quick Checks) project them using the Present button above.
